On 9/2/05, maitrikaruna <kevin@...> wrote:
> John
> 
> I have=
 to agree with Jeff here...my instincts tell me that NEAT
> should be highl=
y amenable to finding optimum network structures that
> have desired result=
s...
> 
> I will say though that this is a thorny problem.  figuring out ho=
w
> to properly handle firing sequences, feedback, etc will be
> challengin=
g.  ideally you want it to eventually find a network where
> the output can=
 actually generate the input.
> 
> They have shown that we have one neuron =
to identify a particular
> face.  That is the neuron at the top of the hier=
archy.  If this is
> the "elvis" neuron, even when I say "elvis" you get a =
picture of
> Elvis in your head.  This is the feedback from that one neuron=
 back
> to the outputs simulating the visual input IMO.  This feedback also=

> allows us to fill in missing pieces...i.e.- i show you a picture of
> ha=
lf of elvis' face, your brain fills in the rest.

I remember that story, to=
o.

That is an oversimplification.  The memory isn't stored in that one
neu=
ron.  But that neuron always gets activated whenever that one
CONCEPT is ac=
tivated, whether it be via a picture or a name or the
sound of a voice or w=
hatever.  That is because of the 'shape' of the
concept.  What do I mean by=
 shape?  I mean in the generalized sense of
the word, meaning 'structure' o=
r how the N dimensions of a thing are
connected in the 'space' of the world=
 in which it lives.  In the case
of concepts in the brain, it may not be a =
3-D space and it WILL NOT be
a 3 dimensional 'shape'.  Part of the 'shape' =
will be like the power
distribution you get when you look at a spectrum ana=
lyzer of a sound. 
Because of course, time is a factor.

> If a NEAT + Hawk=
ins approach works in something like visual
> recognition, this would be gr=
oundbreaking for sure.  Mainly because
> if it works there it should work i=
n other seneory domains as well.

Again, NEAT just evolves topology.

Ken, =
in your game where you embed NEAT in into characters, do you
evolve the cha=
racter over time as opposed to keeping it fixed for its
lifetime?  If so, r=
oughly how have you done this?

> I also think it might be necessary to see=
d NEAT with a somewhat more
> complex beginning structure here because I be=
lieve a certain minimum
> of links/nodes both recurrent and otherwise will =
be necessary as a
> baseline...then let NEAT expand from there.

Yes and no=
.  Part of the 'structure' may exist in the 'real world' in
the form of sen=
ses that provide feedback which are in fact impacted by
outputs.  For examp=
le, a robot that used an output to cause the wheel
to turn, would also have=
 an input that is triggered when that wheel
turns.  Thus, the 'brain' learn=
s to associate the input and the
output.  The feedback happens by means of =
the body, not the brain
itself.  Brain-only feedback would evolve from ther=
e.
